title: If specific gravity of liquid is 0.80, make calculations for its mass density, specific volume, and specific weight? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let’s take the unit to be kg/m^3. Specific gravity = density of material/density of water. So, density of material(in kg/m^3) = specific gravity. So, DENSITY = 0.8 kg/m^3. If 1m^3 of the substance is taken, it’s mass will be 0.8 kg. Specific volume = volume/mass = 1/density. So, Specific Volume = 1/0.8 m^3/kg. SPECIFIC VOLUME = 1.25 m^3/kg. Specific weight = specific gravity * acceleration of gravity. So, specific weight = 0.8kg/m^3 * 9.81 m/s^2. So, SPECIFIC WEIGHT = 7.848 kgm^-2s^-2

Specific gravity of the liquid =Density of the liquid/Density of water . Density means mass density ie mass per unit volume. Thus mass density of the liquid = Mass density of water × specific gravity of the liquid= 1×0.8 gm/cc=0.8 gm/cc . Specific volume=Volume per unit mass = 1/mass density=1/0.8 cc/gm=1.25 cc/g. Specific weight = weight per unit volume = Mass density ×g=0.8g Newton/cc.
